entries.title: Residentes de Chicago varados en México ahora tienen opciones para volar a casa tras la violencia del cártel
entries.summary: <p>Beckie Menzie llegó a Puerto Vallarta la noche del sábado antes de dirigirse a un AirBnB en la Zona Romántica, lista para una semana en México dando clases de música a estudiantes entusiastas de diversas ciudades.</p><p>Pero despertó la siguiente mañana con lo que sonaba como disparos, que resultaron ser bombas incendiarias lanzadas a autos vacíos mientras el humo se elevaba en varios puntos de la ciudad. Para la tarde, ella y otros tuvieron que correr a la calle para refugiarse en otro edificio mientras más bombas estallaban, incendiando una tienda de colchones cercana.</p><p>“Estábamos refugiados en el lugar, no podíamos salir”, contó Menzie.</p><div class="RichTextSidebarModule Enhancement" data-module data-align-center><a class="AnchorLink" id="module-0d0000" name="module-0d0000"></a> <div class="RichTextModule-items RichTextBody"><h3>La Voz Chicago WhatsApp</h3>Encuentra más noticias en nuestro canal de WhatsApp. <a class="Link" href="https://www.whatsapp.com/channel/0029Vb0XT1XCHDylm3rCs40P" target="_blank" ><b>Síguenos.</b></a></div> </div><p>Ella estaba entre muchos habitantes de Chicago que visitaban ciudades mexicanas conmocionadas por la violencia del cártel durante el fin de semana y que ahora tienen esperanzas de regresar a casa a medida que se despejan los bloqueos en las carreteras y se reanudan las operaciones en los aeropuertos.</p><p>Los disturbios en el estado de Jalisco ocurrieron después de que el Ejército Mexicano matara al líder del Cártel Jalisco Nueva Generación (CJNG), Nemesio Rubén Oseguera Cervantes, conocido como “El Mencho”, lo que llevó a al menos 48 horas de bloqueos e incertidumbre.</p><p>Videos en las redes sociales mostraron el retorno del tráfico peatonal y vehicular en algunas ciudades y pueblos el martes, mientras los residentes evaluaban los daños y los turistas hacían planes para irse.</p><p>Menzie dijo que cientos de personas se habían puesto en contacto con ella para saber cómo estaba, aunque mencionó que se encontraba bien, salvo por el susto provocado por los helicópteros que sobrevolaban. Pero por otro lado, dijo haber visto mucha desinformación circulando en las redes sociales, lo que dificultaba discernir lo que realmente estaba sucediendo o encontrar información precisa sobre las órdenes de refugio.</p><p>“Lo bueno de las redes sociales es que pudimos mantenernos en contacto”, contó Menzie. “Lo malo es que no podías escapar de ello, y parte de la información no era cierta”.</p><p>El Departamento de Estado de Estados Unidos confirmó tarde el lunes que las carreteras cerradas debido a la violencia —o bloqueadas por coches incendiados por miembros del cártel— estaban reabriendo, salvo algunas entre Guadalajara y la ciudad turística de Puerto Vallarta. Funcionarios del gobierno también informaron que múltiples aerolíneas habían reanudado operaciones en los aeropuertos de Guadalajara y Puerto Vallarta.</p><p>Cinco vuelos a Chicago estaban entre los 100 cancelados desde Puerto Vallarta el domingo y el lunes después de que videos publicados en redes sociales mostraran el caos en los aeropuertos, según el sitio web de seguimiento FlightAware.</p><p>Un vuelo de United Airlines de Puerto Vallarta salió el lunes por la tarde y aterrizó en Chicago por la noche. Un vocero de la aerolínea dijo que las operaciones completas se reanudaron en ese aeropuerto y en Guadalajara el lunes.</p><p>American Airlines anunció que planeaba reanudar sus operaciones en ambos aeropuertos el martes con cuatro vuelos adicionales entre Puerto Vallarta y Estados Unidos, sumando 750 asientos extra. Un vuelo de American estaba programado directamente a Chicago el martes por la tarde.</p><p>Los viajeros de United y American podrían cambiar sus vuelos sin cargo para regresar a Estados Unidos, dijeron las aerolíneas. Los vuelos de AeroMéxico, VivaAerobus y Volaris dentro y fuera de Guadalajara, incluidos los vuelos hacia Estados Unidos, también estaban operando normalmente el martes.</p><p>El Departamento de Estado aún aconsejaba a los estadounidenses que buscaran refugio y minimizaran movimientos innecesarios, así como confirmar que los vuelos estaban listos para la salida antes de dirigirse al aeropuerto.</p><p>El vuelo de Menzie está programado para salir el viernes, y con el aeropuerto abierto, dijo que no espera ningún problema. Caminó por las principales vías de la ciudad y fue a mercados el martes, y aunque se encontró con largas filas, mencionó que nunca hubo una sensación de peligro.</p><p>“Estamos vigilando nuestros vuelos”, agregó Menzie. “Me sentí bastante segura hoy... Estoy convencida de que saldremos el viernes”.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>

entries.title: Ben Johnson's next trick: getting Bears to forget 2025 and start the climb again
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — In his first year as a head coach at any level, Ben Johnson led the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> to a six-game turnaround, won the franchise’s first playoff game in 15 years and received down-ballot Coach of the Year votes.</p><p>For Johnson’s next trick, he’ll be attempting one of the hardest things in sports — getting his team to forget what happened last year and attempt to climb the mountain again. Flushing the successes is, in many ways, more challenging than turning the page after a tough season.</p><p>Johnson has been clear all offseason that the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears/2026/02/25/bears-nfl-scouting-combine-add-pass-rushers-edge-draft-trade-free-agency-maxx-crosby-zion-young-tj-parker" target="_blank" >Bears</a> don’t get a head start on their 2026 journey just because they won the NFC North last year. Just three days after their season ended with an overtime loss to the Rams, Johnson declared his team was “back to the bottom again.”</p><p>He continued with that message at this week’s NFL Scouting Combine.</p><p>“We’ve got to give more than what we gave a year ago – coaching staff, players, everyone in that building,” he said. “We have to do a little bit more. And so when you look at it that way, yeah, we are back to ground zero, and we’ve got to continue to build on this thing.”</p><p>In 20 of the past 23 NFL seasons, at least one team — including last year’s Bears — has won its division after finishing last in it the year before. For every team that jumps up, though, one has to fall.</p><p>The Bears, who have posted consecutive 10-plus-win seasons just once since 1992, don’t have to look far for examples. The Lions and Vikings went a combined 29-5 in 2024. Last year, they went 18-16 and both missed the playoffs.</p><p>The Bears’ first step in trying to avoid the same fate is to acknowledge the challenge out loud.</p><p>“The moment you get comfortable and think you can take success from one year and just apply it to the next, you can be in for a rude awakening,” general manager Ryan Poles said. “The mindset that we have to have is starting fresh, rebuilding the foundation that we had, and then improving where we need to improve, specifically where our struggles are.</p><p>“If we have that mindset, we'll be good. If the mindset is, we'll be good just because we were good last year, I think you're setting yourself up for failure.”</p><p>The Bears know they need to fix via the draft, trades and free agency — and it’s mostly on defense. They need an improved pass rush from the edge and tackle spots. With Tremaine Edmunds on his way out, they must find at least one starting linebacker. They want Kevin Byard back, but currently have two starting safety vacancies. If Nahshon Wright leaves via free agency, the Bears will likely eye adding an outside cornerback.</p><p>On offense, the Bears have a vacancy to fill at left tackle.</p><p>Johnson has been more active in the Bears’ offseason planning than he was last February, when he was busy assembling a coaching staff. He attends draft meetings and, along with defensive coordinator Dennis Allen and other assistants, communicates to Poles exactly the types of players he’s looking for.That includes body type and skillset preferences, but also mental makeup and the prospects they fit into the Bears’ playing style.</p><p>“The more that we talk and go through, or watch guys and have conversations about our own guys, the more clarity we get from what they want,” Poles said.</p><p>There are obvious advantages to Johnson being in his second year. Quarterback Caleb Williams and his teammates don’t need to learn a new playbook. Defensive players know what Allen expects. The standards that Johnson so carefully built last season, off the field and on, are established.</p><p>In that sense, the Bears aren’t back at square one.</p><p>In so many other ways, they are.</p><p>“It does help frame our mindset,” Johnson said, “that we are going to have to give more.” <br></p>

entries.title: What we know about Rev. Jesse Jackson's death and plans to honor his life
entries.summary: <p>The Rev. Jesse Jackson <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/obituaries/2026/02/17/rev-jesse-jackson-civil-rights-leader-rainbow-push-obituary" target="_blank" >“died peacefully”</a> Feb. 17, his family said during a news conference last week. He was 84. </p><p>Jackson is a Chicago icon known for his work as a civil rights leader. "All are welcome" for services scheduled this week, according to his family.</p><h3>When are services?</h3><p>Jackson will lie in repose <b>Thursday </b>and <b>Friday</b>, at Rainbow PUSH's Kenwood headquarters at 930 E. 50th St. The services both days will start at 10 a.m. Doors will close to the public and media at 9 p.m. </p><p>The service dates were adjusted after officials in South Carolina and Washington, D.C., offered to memorialize him there as well, so his remains will be traveling between Sunday and March 5.</p><p>On <b>March 2</b>, a full day of recognition will take place at and near the South Carolina state capitol, according to communications from Rainbow PUSH. </p><p>Jackson will lie in repose at the Statehouse in Columbia before private, public and church services take place throughout the day. A formal service will take place at 10 a.m. at 1100 Gervais St., Columbia, S.C., 29208. Later that afternoon, a tribute service will be held at Brookland Baptist Church from 4 p.m. to 6 p.m at 1066 Sunset Blvd. Pastor Charles B. Jackson, Sr. will be officiating. </p><p>On <b>March 4</b>, a formal service will take place in Washington, D.C. Details are forthcoming. </p><p>Omega Psi Phi Fraternity Incorporated, a Divine Nine fraternity that Jackson was part of, will hold a celebration of life service on <b>March 5</b>. Details are forthcoming.</p><p>A "People's Celebration" in Chicago will be held at 10 a.m. <b>March 6</b>, at House of Hope, 752 E. 114th St. Doors open at 9 a.m.</p><p>Private homegoing services are scheduled for 10 a.m. <b>March 7</b>, at Rainbow PUSH. Doors open at 8 a.m., with limited capacity. </p><p>Relatives of Jackson said that "all are welcome," regardless of political party.</p><p>"Do not bring your politics, out of respect to Rev. Jesse Jackson and the life that he lived, to these homegoing services. They come respectful and come to say thank you," Jesse Jackson Jr. said during a media event in front of the Jackson family home. "But these homegoing services are welcome to all — Democrat, Republican, liberal and conservative, right wing, left wing, because his life is broad enough to cover the full spectrum of what it means to be an American."</p><p>The family will livestream all services at JesseJacksonLegacy.com. </p><h3>How are Chicagoans paying their respects at the services?</h3><p>Hundreds gathered at <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago/2026/02/26/rev-jesse-jackson-lying-in-repose-rainbow-push-chicago" >Rainbow PUSH on Thursday</a> to pay their respects to Jackson. The family procession arrived after 8 a.m. As the morning wore on, hundreds were lined up to show their gratitude for Jackson and be a part of a historical moment. </p><p>Mayor Brandon Johnson and Rev. Al Sharpton were in attendance on Thursday to pay their respects.</p><p>"We spent a lifetime together," said Sharpton outside the Rainbow PUSH headquarters. "He raised a generation of us and he never gave up, even when he was sick." </p><h3>What hotels are recommended for those traveling to Chicago for the events?</h3><p>Those traveling to Chicago to attend services are encouraged to stay at the Hyatt Regency McCormick Place Chicago at 2233 S. Martin Luther King Drive, according to the family's website. Rooms at the hotel have been reserved within a hotel block, with limited availability. </p><h3>Where can people park?</h3><p>For those hoping to attend the Jackson lying in state events, street parking is available at Rainbow PUSH on South Drexel Boulevard, East 49th Street, East Hyde Park Boulevard and East 49th Street. </p><p>For the People's Celebration, parking will be available at House of Hope's parking lot on 113th Street. </p><h3>What security measures will be in place?</h3><p>At each event, security checks and magnetometers will be in place. The family's website asks that individuals limit items brought to smooth the process. Weapons, signs and any items that could disrupt services are prohibited</p><p>For more information on the scheduled services visit <a class="Link" href="https://www.jessejacksonlegacy.com/" target="_blank" >jessejacksonlegacy.com</a>. </p><h3>Where will the Rev. Jesse Jackson be buried?</h3><p>Jackson will be buried at <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/curious-city/2025/06/04/prejudice-follows-us-to-the-grave-the-segregated-past-of-chicago-cemeteries#:~:text=Mayor%20Harold%20Washington%20is%20buried,bring%20it%20to%20an%20end." target="_blank" >Oak Woods Cemetery</a>, the largest cemetery on the South Side, in Greater Grand Crossing. Former Chicago Mayor Harold Washington, journalist and civil rights activist Ida B. Wells and Olympic athlete Jesse Owens are among those buried there.</p><h3>How did he die?</h3><p>While his family has not given an official cause of death nor said where he died, Jackson had been declining in health for a decade before his death. In 2015,<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/2017/11/17/18375473/rev-jesse-jackson-announces-parkinson-s-diagnosis" > Jackson was initially diagnosed with Parkinson’s disease</a>, but he revealed last April that he actually had progressive supranuclear palsy.</p><h3>How is the political world reacting to his death?</h3><p>Political figures from across the country have weighed in to pay their respects and honor his legacy. </p><p>In a joint statement, former President Barack Obama and former first lady Michelle Obama wrote: "Michelle and I will always be grateful for Jesse's lifetime of service, and the friendship our families share. We stood on his shoulders. We send our deepest condolences to the Jackson family and everyone in Chicago and beyond who knew and loved him." </p><p>President Donald Trump also extended his sympathies to Jackson's family in a statement posted to Truth Social last week. </p><p>"I knew him well, long before becoming President," he said. "He was very gregarious — Someone who truly loved people! Despite the fact that I am falsely and consistently called a Racist by the Scoundrels and Lunatics on the Radical Left, Democrats ALL, it was always my pleasure to help Jesse along the way."</p><p>Chicago leaders, including Mayor Brandon Johnson and Gov. JB Pritzker, also shared their condolences. </p><p>"In honor of Rev. Jackson's service, and as our city mourns, the Chicago flag will lower to half-staff," Mayor Johnson wrote in a statement. </p><p>Pritzker also ordered all flags across the state to fly at half-mast to honor him in a statement posted on social media.</p><p>"He broke down barriers, inspired generations, and kept hope alive. Our state, nation, and world are better due to his years of service," Pritzker said.</p><h3>How are Chicagoans reacting to his death?</h3><p>Across the city, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/news/2026/02/17/jesse-jackson-chicago-remembers" >Chicago residents mourned Jackson’s death</a> and urged that his legacy continue. </p><p>Martin Travis, a congregant of Apostolic Church of God in Woodlawn, said in his youth, his parents brought him to demonstrations organized by Operation Breadbasket, a movement Jackson led. </p><p>Now, 64, Travis remembers Jackson as "instrumental in fighting for justice and freedom for all people."</p><p>Chloe Gould, 41, a Bronzeville resident, said that his death hit "like you lost a family member." </p><p>In the wake of his death, she said she worries about the future of civil rights activism, as other activists and leaders have not stepped in to fill his shoes. </p><p>"Who is gonna be the civil rights activist now?" she asked. </p>

entries.title: CPS to shut down financially distressed ASPIRA campuses, scattering students to new schools
entries.summary: <p>Chicago Public Schools officials told leaders of the ASPIRA charter school network Wednesday night that the district is transferring students out of their two high schools for the remainder of the school year.</p><p>This is an unprecedented move by the school district that will disrupt the education of some 545 students.</p><p>CPS officials told the financially distressed charter network that it was taking this action to “safeguard students’ educational stability” and to make sure it’s complying with state and federal laws. ASPIRA has been relying on cash advances from CPS to make payroll, but the state limits how much CPS can do that.</p><p>“To be clear, CPS is not revoking ASPIRA’s charter at this time, but is moving forward with a student transition process as oversight, due to the emergency situation created by ASPIRA’s failure to demonstrate financial sustainability, which places the education of ASPIRA’s students at risk,” CPS told ASPIRA’s board president David Rodriguez and other ASPIRA board members in a letter.</p><p>Seniors from ASPIRA’s two high schools will be at the CPS board meeting Thursday to try to convince members to change their minds. Just last month, some board members said they were reluctant to keep giving ASPIRA cash advances, even as they sympathize with how this decision impacts students.</p><p>Eighteen-year-old Angeline Melody Solis said she wants the board to keep that top of mind.</p><p>“We don't control the money and where the money goes so it really sucks that at the end of the day, we face the most consequences,” she told WBEZ in an interview Wednesday. “The students have so many concerns about college and their credits. There's just so many things that should have been taken into account, besides the money.”</p><p>CPS officials made this decision after they gave ASPIRA a Tuesday deadline to find outside funding to make it through the school year and to submit a financial plan for the future. ASPIRA responded by saying it was trying to get a bridge loan and would fundraise, according to documents provided to WBEZ by CPS.</p><p>ASPIRA leaders also demanded that CPS give the charter network four years of retroactive funding to make up for what ASPIRA’s leaders believe is a chronic underfunding of all charter schools.</p><p>CPS officials rejected this, saying there is no way to give back funding once the budget for past years is closed. They also said that ASPIRA’s response to CPS’ demands were insufficient.</p><p>The back-and-forth between ASPRIA and CPS has been going on for months, with both sides blaming each other for the network’s financial problems.</p><p>CPS contracts with private organizations to run charter schools and, at the recommendation of CPS leaders, board members renewed ASPIRA’s contract in April 2025.</p><p>As it did with many recent charter renewals, CPS gave ASPIRA a shorter two-year contract and imposed several conditions, including that it participate in a “financial remediation” program that requires the network to submit monthly cash flow statements so the district can conduct additional oversight.</p><p>But the charter network had financial struggles throughout the school year. In November, <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/education/2025/11/19/chicago-public-schools-aspira-charter-network-finances-cps-investigation" target="_blank" ><u>WBEZ and the Sun-Times previously reported</u></a>, CPS sent ASPIRA a letter after a months-long investigation blasting the charter network’s leadership for “a failure of governance” and “a lack of financial proficiency necessary to successfully run a school.”</p><p>ASPIRA’s executive director Edgar Lopez responded that the charter school network did not have enough money to make payroll through the end of the school year. He said the charter network needed $4.5 million.</p><p><a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/education/2025/11/25/cps-to-help-aspira-make-payroll-but-charter-operators-financial-woes-remain" target="_blank" ><u>CPS has given ASPIRA $2.25 million in cash advances</u></a> “to support payroll and continuity of student services,” according to CPS.</p><p>But, when Lopez announced last month that he needed even more to get through the school year, <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/education/2026/02/11/cps-charter-school-cant-make-payroll-insolvent-closed-march-aspira-chiarts-cpsboard" target="_blank" ><u>board members pushed back</u></a> that it would be against the law to continue sending the charter network extra funding.</p><p>State law requires school districts to give charters between 97% and 103% of what they provide for district-run schools. CPS would be over that limit if it kept advancing ASPIRA money.</p><p>Board members also said they worried about the precedent they were setting.</p><p>In just the last two years, four private organizations with contracts to run public schools in Chicago have said they no longer want to operate them.</p><p>Charter schools’ budgets are closely tied to student enrollment and, with an overall <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/09/25/chicago-public-schools-enrollment-drops-restarts-decrease-migrant-students-latino-immigration" target="_blank" ><u>decline in the CPS student population</u></a>, charters are having trouble filling their seats. ASPIRA has the CPS permission to admit up to 1,600 students at its two high schools, but this year started out with less than 600. Charter school operators also cite other issues that have added to their financial troubles, including rising labor costs.</p><p>Board members are <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/education/2025/11/04/cps-chiarts-epic-academy" target="_blank" >taking over management</a> of the Chicago High School for the Arts and <a class="Link" href="https://www.wbez.org/education/2024/12/21/cps-votes-to-spare-7-acero-charter-schools-from-closure-plans-to-absorb-5-in-2026" target="_blank" >five schools run by the Acero School</a>s charter network. But CPS is letting two other Acero schools and a small Southeast Side charter school called EPIC close.</p>
entries.author: Sarah Karp | WBEZ

entries.title: Will there even be a season? And other pressing Sky questions
entries.summary: <p>It’s speculation season in the WNBA, where drawn-out CBA negotiations derailed the usual offseason routine. While players and team owners hash it out, the Sun-Times analyzes the moving parts ahead of the Sky’s 2026 season.</p><p><b>1. Will the season start on time?</b><br>The schedule says “play ball” on May 8, with the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky" target="_blank" >Sky</a> set to open in Portland on May 9. But will they?</p><p>Beyond CBA negotiations, the league still needs to run two expansion drafts, the college draft and a massive free agency period. It now says that if a deal isn’t reached by March 10, the season won’t begin on time.</p><p>The sticking point: a $58 million gap between the two sides’ salary cap proposals. The league claims the players’ proposal would lead to “hundreds of millions of dollars” in losses over the life of the agreement, while the players say it would leave the league in a “profitable position.”</p><p>Nobody can validate any of that, because league financials and projections aren’t public.</p><p>Still, both sides insist they’re trying to avoid a strike or lockout, and say they want a season.</p><p><b>2. What will the Sky roster look like?</b><br>While nothing is set in stone, fans can reasonably expect to see Angel Reese, Kamilla Cardoso, Ajša Sivka, and Courtney Vandersloot in a Sky uniform this season. Vandersloot is a free agent and franchise great who plans to return, and Reese, Cardoso, and Sivka are young building blocks under contract.</p><p>To make this crew competitive, the Sky will need some wins in free agency. The biggest unknown on that front is Ariel Atkins. The Sky traded for the two-time All-Star last season hoping she’d become part of the core, but she hasn’t indicated whether she plans to return.</p><p>There will be plenty of opportunities to take big swings elsewhere, with more than 100 veteran free agents available. Coming off two losing seasons, though, Chicago will be a tough sell for the biggest names.</p><p>The Sky also have Hailey Van Lith and Maddy Westbeld under contract, but one will likely be left unprotected in the expansion draft. (Expansion teams Portland Fire and Toronto Tempo will each be able to pluck one “unprotected” player from every team.)</p><p>Van Lith is <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/12/18/sky-point-guard-hailey-van-lith-enters-a-defining-offseason" >most likely to be protected</a> given where the Sky drafted her in 2025 (No. 11). She’s been rehabbing an ankle injury, and the goal is for her to be ready by the start of the season, per a team source.</p><p><b>3. Who is Sivka and why haven’t I heard of her?</b><br>Sivka was the Sky’s top pick in the 2025 draft (No. 10), but the 20-year old has been playing overseas. A 6’3 sharpshooting wing, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/11/28/setting-expectations-for-20-year-old-sky-prospect-ajsa-sivka" >the Sky love her mobility and quick release</a>. She’s shooting 36.4% from three on 4.7 attempts per game for her Spanish club.</p><p>General manager Jeff Pagliocca told the Sun-Times he expects Sivka to report for the Sky’s 2026 season and play heavy minutes right away. Sivka’s agent did respond in time to a request for confirmation.</p><p><b>4. What’s the latest with Reese?</b><br>Last season raised real doubts about <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/09/11/after-another-losing-season-reese-sky-rift-clouds-future" >Reese’s long-term future in Chicago</a>. Given her talents as a generational rebounder and budding playmaker, she looked to be the face of the franchise for years to come.</p><p>That feels less certain now.</p><p>As another losing season came to a close, Reese’s tone toward the organization changed. She alluded to <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/08/19/angel-reese-alludes-to-tension-regarding-her-recovery-from-back-injury" target="_blank" ><u>disappointment with how her back injury was handled</u></a> and questioned the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/08/21/playoffs-dream-dead-foundation-under-review-for-sky" target="_blank" ><u>organization’s progress</u></a>.</p><p>She told the Tribune that though she’d like to be in Chicago long-term, if “things don’t pan out” she might have to “move in a different direction and do what’s best for me.”</p><p>Sky ownership <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/09/07/whose-idea-was-it-to-suspend-angel-reese" >suspended her</a> over other comments made in that interview, namely demanding a better roster and questioning the wisdom of relying on 37-year-old point guard Courtney Vandersloot.</p><p>Since then, no major flare-ups have occurred. Reese <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2025/12/12/from-usa-basketball-camp-sky-star-angel-reese-quiets-fears-about-a-departure-from-chicago" >has not requested a trade</a> and the Sky expect her back.</p><p>Still, neither side has publicly signaled that the relationship has been repaired.</p><p>Are Reese and the Sky still committed to each other for the long haul? Or are they just biding their time until her rookie contract ends after the 2027 season — or until the right trade partner comes along?</p><p><b>5. Where will the Sky practice? </b><br>At some point during the 2026 season, the Sky will practice <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2026/02/06/skys-new-practice-facility-will-be-ready-by-late-spring-ceo-adam-fox-says" >in their new facility in Bedford Park</a>. It’s one of <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2026/02/13/in-the-wnba-facilities-race-sky-hold-a-momentary-advantage" >only two new practice facilities opening this season</a> and will be among the largest in the league.</p><p>The Sky just released a list of features through the Sports Business Journal including:</p><ul class="rte2-style-ul" style="margin-top:0;margin-bottom:0;padding-inline-start:48px;" id="rte-ff095fd1-134d-11f1-a547-37f7705b3b3e"><li>Two full-size basketball courts</li><li>Weight room</li><li>Performance and recovery areas</li><li>Kitchen with a full-time chef</li><li>Hot and cold tubs, sauna, infrared room, massage room</li><li>Players’ lounge</li><li>On-site doctor’s office</li><li>Mother’s and family room</li><li>Content creation studio and glam stations</li><li>Secure parking lot</li></ul><p>As far as <i>when</i> the building will be available, the Sky’s official projection is “late spring.”</p><p>Dave Brady, the mayor of Bedford Park, told the Sun-Times that much depends on the weather. He thinks there’s a “good chance” that the Sky will be able to use their locker room and weight room by May 1 and expects the courts to be ready by June. In the meantime, the Sky can practice in the attached Wintrust Sports Complex.</p><p>Which means a delayed start to the season may not be the worst thing for the Sky. More time to finish construction and show free agents what's coming.</p><p><b>6. Who will the Sky select at No. 5 in the 2026 college draft?</b><br>LSU’s Flau’jae Johnson and UCLA’s Kiki Rice appeared at No. 5 in recent mock drafts.</p><p>Both are reasonable picks for a team that just needs to add good players. Johnson is one of the most talented guards in her draft class, and while Rice may not have the same star ceiling, she has an explosiveness the Sky need.</p><p>There’s also a wrinkle with Johnson. She and Reese won the national championship together in 2023 at LSU, but since then both have indicated they aren’t friends.</p><p>That doesn't mean they can’t hoop together. But if the Sky are still committed to building around Reese, it’s a dynamic worth weighing.</p><p>In the meantime, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/chicago-sky/2026/02/01/ucla-womens-team-has-something-bruin" >keep an eye on UCLA’s loaded roster</a>. Lauren Betts, Gabriela Jaquez, and Gianna Kneepkens could all fit for the Sky.</p>

entries.title: Former Blackhawks coach Joel Quenneville gets 1,000th win
entries.summary: <p>ANAHEIM, Calif. — Former <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" >Blackhawks</a> coach Joel Quenneville's 1,000th career victory was so dramatic that he almost had to be reminded of the milestone when the clock finally hit zeros on the Anaheim Ducks' 6-5 comeback win.</p><p>When Quenneville stood at center ice with his wife, his daughter and his entire team for a postgame photo moments later Wednesday night, he allowed himself a moment out of the hockey grind to appreciate history.</p><p>"I wasn't prioritizing the number," Quenneville said after joining Scotty Bowman in the most exclusive hockey coaching club. "I just wanted to play well tonight and find a way to win. That was the motivation, and it turned out to be a very special one as well."</p><p>His Ducks rallied to beat two-time defending conference champion Edmonton in their return from the Olympic break, overcoming a pair of two-goal deficits and another one-goal deficit during their frenetic four-goal third period.</p><p>Cutter Gauthier scored the winner with 1:14 to play, and Anaheim hung on for its NHL-leading eighth multigoal comeback win during its first year under Quenneville, whose players all gathered at the bench to mob their coach after the whistle.</p><p>"It was an important game for us in a lot of ways," said Quenneville, who has the second-place Ducks in the Stanley Cup playoff race for the first time since 2018. "They had the puck a lot more than we did, but at the same time, I thought we found a way to win a game. It had other meanings, but to me it was the importance of where it put us in the standings, and coming out of the break, the momentum that we could get off a win like tonight."</p><p>The 67-year-old Quenneville received some fine bottles of wine and cigars among his postgame gifts, but he planned to celebrate just with a beer.</p><p>The second member of the 1,000-win club took a long time to join Bowman, who got his 1,000th with the Detroit Red Wings on Feb. 8, 1997 — just a month after Quenneville coached his very first game with the St. Louis Blues.</p><p>Quenneville reached the mark in his 1,825th game of a career highlighted by three Stanley Cup championships with the Blackhawks. Bowman finished his career in 2002 with 1,244 victories in 2,141 regular-season games, also winning nine Stanley Cup titles as a coach.</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/10/19/joel-quenneville-blackhawks-moved-on-ducks-return-chicago-sexual-assault" >Joel Quenneville, Blackhawks have ‘moved on’ from each other, and his quiet return Sunday proved it</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2021/10/27/22749753/kyle-beach-blackhawks-sexual-assault-victim-name-bradley-aldrich-joel-quenneville-donald-fehr" >Kyle Beach reveals he’s Blackhawks’ sexual-assault victim: ‘The healing process is just beginning’</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/05/08/joel-quenneville-former-blackhawks-coach-hired-by-anaheim-ducks" >Former Blackhawks coach Joel Quenneville hired by Ducks</a> </li> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2021/10/28/22751588/joel-quenneville-resigns-panthers-blackhawks-coach-sexual-assault-kyle-beach-brad-aldrich" >Joel Quenneville out as Panthers coach in aftermath of Blackhawks investigation</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>"He's from a different league when I look at his company," Quenneville said about Bowman, who was a senior adviser of hockey operations to his son, general manager Stan Bowman, during the Blackhawks' successful run under Quenneville.</p><p>"I think he's lonesome up there, the number he's at," Quenneville added. "I had Scotty and Stan in Chicago together. We had some great wins, and he's got a lot of Cups. He's been very successful in the game. ... I'm happy to be getting the opportunity back in the game and be around a team like we've got now."</p><p>Quenneville has made a successful return to the NHL this season in Anaheim after a four-year absence from the league following his <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2021/10/28/22751588/joel-quenneville-resigns-panthers-blackhawks-coach-sexual-assault-kyle-beach-brad-aldrich" >resignation from the Florida Panthers</a> in late 2021 over his inaction during the Blackhawks' sexual abuse scandal 11 years earlier.</p><p>Quenneville's <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2024/07/01/blackhawks-sexual-assault-stan-bowman-joel-qunneville-nhl-reinstated" >NHL ban was lifted</a> in July 2024, and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2025/05/08/joel-quenneville-former-blackhawks-coach-hired-by-anaheim-ducks" >the Ducks hired him</a> one year later to take over a struggling franchise with no playoff appearances in seven consecutive seasons. Anaheim (31-23-3) has vaulted into the thick of the Western Conference playoff race in its first season under Quenneville, who has led his teams to the playoffs in 20 of the 22 NHL seasons he finished behind a bench.</p><p>When asked if there were times when he wondered whether he would have a chance to reach 1,000 wins, Quenneville replied: "It's something that I don't think about. I think my motivation, my goals were always once you win a Cup one time, you can't wait to do it again. It's always been the reason why we're doing what we're doing."</p><p>After playing 13 NHL seasons as a sturdy defenseman with the signature bristly mustache he has sported for his entire adult life, Quenneville has been an NHL head coach for parts of 26 seasons, and he has won at every stop.</p><p>He led the Blues to seven consecutive playoff appearances before his firing. Quenneville then lasted just three seasons in Colorado despite producing two playoff teams.</p><p>He replaced Denis Savard behind the Blackhawks' bench in 2008 and led the Original Six franchise to eight straight playoff appearances and three championships — including the 2010 Stanley Cup, which ended the NHL's longest active drought at 59 seasons.</p><p>Quenneville joined the Panthers in April 2019, but his third season in Florida ended abruptly when the NHL banned him along with Stan Bowman and Al MacIsaac "as a result of their inadequate response upon being informed in 2010 of allegations that <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2021/10/27/22749753/kyle-beach-blackhawks-sexual-assault-victim-name-bradley-aldrich-joel-quenneville-donald-fehr" >Blackhawks player Kyle Beach</a> had been assaulted by the club's video coach," the league said.</p><p>NHL Commissioner Gary Bettman determined Quenneville had showed remorse for his inaction on the allegations that surfaced during Chicago's playoff run to a Stanley Cup title. Quenneville said he also worked with advocacy groups to study the proper ways to lead in such situations.</p><p>Quenneville remained intently focused on the NHL during his four years away from the bench, watching games every night on television from his home in Florida and staying in contact with his countless friends in the game. Those friends included Pat Verbeek, his former teammate with the Hartford Whalers and the Ducks' general manager.</p><p>Verbeek fired Greg Cronin and persuaded owner Henry Samueli to take the potential risk and the definite public-relations hit of hiring Quenneville. The move has worked out splendidly on the ice so far, with the Ducks dramatically improving their record with a talented young core gaining another year of experience.</p><p>Bowman and Quenneville could be joined in the 1,000-win club by two more veteran coaches within the next few seasons.</p><p>Paul Maurice, who won the past two Stanley Cup titles with the Panthers, has 945 career victories with five teams. Lindy Ruff earned his 933rd career victory Wednesday night with the Buffalo Sabres' 2-1 win over New Jersey.<br></p>
entries.author: AP

entries.title: Blackhawks' Connor Murphy feeling allure of playoffs as trade deadline nears
entries.summary: <p>NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Connor Murphy has spent nine long years working as hard as he could to push the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks" target="_blank" >Blackhawks</a> toward the playoffs.</p><p>But now that it seems unlikely he will reach that mountain with the Hawks — his contract expires this summer and many young defensemen are vying to take his spot — the allure of not having to wait longer has crept into his head. A trade would allow him to fulfill his dream this spring.</p><p>Asked Wednesday what he personally wants to see happen before the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2026/02/21/blackhawks-nhl-trade-deadline-preview-connor-murphy-jason-dickinson-ilya-mikheyev" target="_blank" >trade deadline</a> next Friday (March 6), he answered honestly.</p><p>"I don’t know," Murphy said. "I would like to be here. I would like to also play in the playoffs. It’s kind of mixed emotion. That’s why this time is so hard, having that feeling tearing you both ways. It’s not an easy answer either way."</p><p>Throughout 12-plus NHL seasons, Murphy has never played in a playoff game attended by fans. His only berth came in the 2020 COVID bubble in Edmonton, which hardly resembled a real postseason.</p><p>His contract, which carries a $4.4 million salary-cap hit, technically allows him only to submit a 10-team no-trade list, but the Hawks will make sure to do right by their longest-tenured player and longtime alternate captain in any trade that materializes.</p><p>And doing right by him likely means sending him to a team that's a strong bet to make the playoffs — with decent odds of making a deep run.</p><p>"It’s an odd thing, the potential to get traded to a team that’s in that spot," he said. "I’ve been so focused for nine years on wanting to make the playoffs here, and wanting to play our best and grow as a team...be a better leader and teammate to help push it along. It’s a funny situation. It’s just interesting how the business side can change and pull you to a different direction."</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2026/01/28/blackhawks-connor-murphy-reflects-on-tenure-chicago-home-patience" >As Connor Murphy’s Blackhawks tenure nears its end, he still dreams about rewarding Chicago for its patience</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Veteran right-handed defensemen are desirable at the deadline every year, and this year is no different. No contending team ever believes they have enough depth in that category. The Stars, Red Wings and Sabres stand out as three probable playoff teams with the strongest need.</p><p>There's no shortage of veteran right-handed defensemen available on the market, though. Besides Murphy, the list also includes Tyler Myers (Canucks), Dougie Hamilton (Devils), Justin Faulk (Blues), Luke Schenn (Jets) and Rasmus Ristolainen (Flyers).</p><p>A second-round pick would represent a solid return for Murphy, but Hawks general manager Kyle Davidson might have to maneuver the market cleverly to achieve that.</p><p>Nonetheless, Hawks players and coaches have taken the past week to discuss and recognize Murphy's immense <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/blackhawks/2026/01/28/blackhawks-connor-murphy-reflects-on-tenure-chicago-home-patience" target="_blank" >impact on Chicago</a> and on the organization, suggesting they all believe a trade is coming.</p><p>Murphy sounds like a man who expects to live elsewhere two weeks from now, too. He has told his wife, Kristina, a Chicago native, to be prepared to move.</p><p>"[Connor has] played really well," coach Jeff Blashill said. "There was a time, earlier in the year, where he wasn't given lots of minutes. He's really done a good job earning ice time on a consistent basis. </p><p>"He's a huge reason why our [penalty] kill has been really successful. He's defended really well; he's moved the puck well. He's shown some scoring. He's been physical. He's fought. All those things are an important part of leadership."</p><p>In the meantime, Murphy must squash his drifting thoughts and focus on the hockey at hand: his likely final road trip in a red sweater. He's expected to be in the lineup Thursday against the Predators, and the Hawks have three more games after that before the deadline.</p><p>"[I'm] just focusing on trying to get your body and mind into game-play again," Murphy said. "Because no matter what happens, you want to be playing your best and feeling your best."</p><p></p><p></p><bsp-list-loadmore class="PageListH" data-module data-hide-authors="true" entries.title: Indiana's Bears stadium bill advances, awaits governor's signature
entries.summary: <p>INDIANAPOLIS — The state of Indiana took another step in their effort to lure the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears" target="_blank" >Bears</a> to Hammond when, on Thursday, the Indiana State Senate passed the bill to establish the Northwest Indiana Stadium Authority. Gov. Mike Braun must now sign it into law, which is expected. The bill passed 45-4.</p><p>All that’s left is for the <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium" target="_blank" >Bears</a> to decide between Hammond and Arlington Heights.</p><p>“We sure give the Bears a lot to think about to come here,” state senator Rick Niemeyer said. “I think it’s very serious.”</p><p>Niemeyer, from Lowell, acknowledged that the Bears have flirted with moving to Indiana off and on over the years.</p><p>“It’s a little different this time,” he said. “I think it’s very serious.”</p><div class="RelatedList Enhancement" data-module data-align-center> <div class="RelatedList-title">Related</div> <ul class="RelatedList-items"> <li class="RelatedList-items-item"> <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/02/26/chicago-bears-property-tax-incentives-illinois-house-city-opposition-arlington-heights-proposed-stadium" >Chicago Bears property tax incentives advance in Illinois House over city opposition</a> </li> </ul> </div> <p>Sen. Ron Alting, an avowed Colts fan, was quick to say he wore No. 51 from seventh grade through high school because he admired star Dick Butkus.</p><p>“He was my man,” he said.</p><p>Senate Bill 27 empowers the NISA to acquire and finance a Bears stadium. It also would be tasked with construction, equipping, operating and maintenance of the proposed domed stadium near Wolf Lake in Hammond. The bill would draw financing from Lake County and Porter County food and beverage tax and the Lake County inkeeper’s tax. Hammond would also impose an admissions tax and the state would renegotiate toll road fees.</p><p>State senator Ryan Mishler, who authored the bill, said the Bears could break ground in spring 2027, though there might be work done to the site this year. He praised Bears officials, saying it was a “privilege to work with those folks and learn more about their families.”</p><p>State senator Lonnie Randolph, who represents Hammond, Munster, East Chicago, Whiting and parts of Highland, praised the potential “enormous” economic impact of a stadium.</p><p>“This Bears thing is a major historical event,” he said.</p><p>The Bears have said they would pay $2 billion to build a stadium, be it in Hammond or Arlington Heights. The team owns the 326 acres at the former Arlington International Racecourse but is wants to pay lower property taxes. The Bears would keep any proceeds from naming rights of either stadium.</p><p>Just steps from the NFL Scouting Combine, the Indiana House of Representatives passed the bill by a 95-4 vote on Tuesday. The state’s legislative session ends Friday.</p><p>Bears chairman George McCaskey and president Kevin Warren made their usual trip to the NFL Scouting Combine but were not present during the votes Tuesday or Thursday.</p><p>On Tuesday, general manager Ryan Poles smiled when asked whether he had paid attention to the Bears’ dance with Arlington Heights and Hammond. Poles was swimming in a hotel pool in Grand Cayman a few weeks ago when Bears fans started telling him where they wanted the stadium.</p><p>“I’ve got a lot of faith in Kevin and George to get that done and do what's best for our organization, our fan base,” he said. “There's a lot of pieces involved with that. But like I said, I've got enough to worry about with the roster."</p><p>In the last 22 months, the Bears have declared three separate sites as the only location that worked for them — first a Lakefront plot south of Soldier Field, then Arlington Heights and then, earlier this month, Hammond. The Bears first turned their attention to Indiana when Warren sent a letter to season ticket-holders in December saying the team had been told by Illinois lawmakers that “our project will not be a priority in 2026.”</p><p>Thursday, the<a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/02/26/chicago-bears-property-tax-incentives-illinois-house-city-opposition-arlington-heights-proposed-stadium" target="_blank" > Illinois Finance and Revenue Committee </a>passed the so-called mega-project bill to allow the Bears to negotiate property taxes, sending it to the House floor.</p>
entries.author: Patrick Finley

entries.title: Chicago Bears property tax incentives advance in Illinois House over city opposition
entries.summary: <p>A tax incentive plan aimed at keeping the Bears in Illinois advanced in the state House Thursday amid opposition from City Hall and questions about whether Democrats can whip up enough votes to pass it.</p><p>The legislation, introduced by state Rep. Kam Buckner (D-Chicago), would allow the NFL team to negotiate a freeze on property tax assessments with local taxing districts — in this case, Arlington Heights, Cook County and local school districts.</p><p>This marks the latest development in the high-stakes bidding war between Illinois and <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/02/19/chicago-bears-stadium-hammond-indiana-move" >Indiana</a> over which state can lay claim to one of the NFL’s most storied franchises as the team looks for the exits from its long-time lease at Soldier Field.</p><p>On a roll call opposed by Republicans, the Democratic-led House Revenue & Finance Committee voted 13-7 to back Buckner’s legislation and position it for a vote by the full House. But that didn't happen after the committee vote because the House adjourned for the week without taking action on the measure.</p><p>Following the committee's action, Buckner said it’s time to start putting a legislative plan into motion, and the property tax concessions are essential for anything going forward.</p><p>“I don't feel pressured by the Bears,” Buckner said. “What is important to me, though, is that we are able to put these tools in play. I do want the team to stay in Illinois. That's very important to me.”</p><p>The bill that advanced Thursday deals only with the issue of property tax certainty and saving the Bears hundreds of millions of dollars by freezing property taxes on the Arlington International Racecourse site, and allowing the team to negotiate reduced “payments in lieu of property taxes with suburban school districts.”</p><p>Still to be determined is the massive infusion of infrastructure funding required to bankroll the road, sewer and utility work needed to ready the site for development.</p><p>Ahead of the vote, Buckner appeared on <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/fran-spielman-show" >“The Fran Spielman Show”</a> podcast and said the infrastructure wish list that started at $855 million has been whittled down to $734 million and said, “We’re still talking through it.”</p><p>But Buckner told the Chicago Sun-Times that whatever the final number turns out to be, the Chicago legislative delegation will demand similar help to renovate and refresh Soldier Field and ease the transportation bottleneck that makes it difficult to get in and out of the Museum Campus.</p><p>“We’ve still got some things to work on, including Chicago and what happens with Chicago and a Chicago package,” he said.</p><p>Buckner, whose district includes Soldier Field, has long spoken out against the state cutting a blank check to finance a new Bears’ stadium, particularly given that roughly half a billion dollars in debt remains from the 2003 renovation of Soldier Field. Buckner said the Bears should pick up that tab.</p><p>The Chicago Park District has made an ask for <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/bears-stadium/2026/02/24/soldier-field-renovation-post-chicago-bears-era-illinois-general-assembly" >$630 million</a> for infrastructure and renovation of the Soldier Field — an appeal that a representative of the mayor’s office renewed today despite formally registering as an opponent to Buckner’s legislation.</p><p>Steven Mahr, Chicago’s acting chief financial officer, told the House panel the relocation of the Bears would have “devastating consequences on the city,” and he re-upped the city’s previous $630 million infrastructure request.</p><p>“Some of those consequences are unknowable,” Mahr said. “It is clear that Chicago is the economic engine of the state of Illinois. Engines require fuel to run, otherwise engines stall and grind to a halt. The city is requesting a fair and equitable opportunity and a level playing field.”</p><p>Labor unions, business groups and several northwest suburbs, including Arlington Heights, voiced support for the legislation.</p><p><i>This is a developing story.</i></p>

entries.title: Fundación de Chicago otorga $15 millones para la construcción de dos centros comunitarios en el lado oeste
entries.summary: <p>Los dos hijos de Richard Townsell crecieron practicando deportes, lo que a menudo significaba conducir de 45 minutos a una hora para asistir a prácticas fuera de los límites de la ciudad.</p><p>Y si la práctica no implicaba viajar, requería un poco de trabajo adicional.</p><p>“Entreno [lucha libre] en la Chicago Hope Academy. Practicamos en la cancha de baloncesto, y tenemos que enrollar los tapices al final de cada práctica”, dijo Townsell, director ejecutivo de Lawndale Christian Development Corp. “Tenemos una instalación vieja, y ese es el caso para muchos atletas de las Escuelas Públicas de Chicago. No tienen una instalación permanente”.</p><p>Pero eso pronto cambiará para muchos estudiantes y jóvenes en el lado oeste.</p><p>La Fundación Lohengrin, con sede en Chicago, anunció el miércoles que Lawndale Christian Development y Erie Neighborhood House recibirán $10 millones y $5 millones, respectivamente, para la construcción de dos nuevos centros comunitarios y juveniles en el lado oeste.</p><p>El premio proviene de la iniciativa “Thriving Youth, Stronger Communities”, que se lanzó en 2024 para ayudar a crear entornos donde los jóvenes de Chicago puedan crecer y prosperar.</p><p>Lawndale Christian Development y Erie Neighborhood House son los primeros en recibir el premio, dijo Mark Rodríguez, director ejecutivo de la Fundación Lohengrin.</p><p>Los $10 millones apoyarán el proyecto de Lawndale Christian Development, <a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/real-estate/2025/11/20/plan-commission-approves-depaul-practice-facility-morgan-park-commons" target="_blank" >One Lawndale</a>, que fue aprobado por el Concejo Municipal a finales de 2025.</p><p>El premio “hace posible [One Lawndale]”, dijo Richard Townsell, director ejecutivo de Lawndale Christian Development.</p><p>“Con la Fundación Lohengrin siendo la primera en entrar, ayuda a asegurar a todos los demás”, dijo Townsell. Añadió que un premio de este tamaño puede ayudar a atraer inversores y financiamiento adicionales.</p><p>One Lawndale, localizado en la esquina de Springfield Avenue y Cermak Road, será un complejo deportivo pionero para el lado oeste. El centro deportivo y de recreación bajo techo de $38 millones permitirá la práctica de deportes durante todo el año, con dos campos de césped interior, seis canchas de baloncesto de tamaño completo, una sala de boxeo y acondicionamiento físico, un estudio de lucha libre, un salón multipropósito, áreas de comida y bar y una tienda profesional.</p><p>Las ligas deportivas, los programas de mentoría y otras iniciativas estarán dirigidas por socios liderados por personas afroamericanas y latinas de North Lawndale y La Villita (South Lawndale).</p><p>Uno de los objetivos de la iniciativa “Thriving Youth, Stronger Communities” es crear espacios seguros para los jóvenes para ayudar en la prevención de la violencia.</p><p>Townsell cree que One Lawndale logrará eso ya que también ofrecerá programas de nutrición, salud mental y mentoría.</p><p>“Pensamos que algunas de las mejores acciones de prevención de la violencia que se pueden hacer son trabajar con jóvenes antes de que se vean involucrados en comportamientos por aburrimiento o porque realmente no tienen nada más que hacer”, agregó Townsell. “Para nosotros, poder tener algo así en el vecindario que sea de alta calidad y que tenga todos los demás apoyos necesarios, creemos que será el mejor esfuerzo en prevención de la violencia y construcción de comunidad”.</p><p>La Fundación Lohengrin está ayudando al desarrollador a encontrar otros socios fundacionales para cerrar su brecha de financiamiento, dijo Townsell. Espera comenzar la construcción a finales del verano o principios del otoño. Se prevé que esté terminado para el otoño o invierno de 2027.</p><p>Erie Neighborhood House utilizará su premio de $5 millones para el Centro de Erie House en La Villita.</p><p>La organización de servicios sociales ha estado en La Villita durante aproximadamente 20 años. Actualmente alquila un edificio en el vecindario.</p><p>La Villita Erie House, ubicada en 2653-59 S. Kildare Ave., permitirá a la organización no lucrativa ampliar su huella en el vecindario, tanto en el número de personas a las que sirve como en un espacio más grande y permanente. El edificio de cinco pisos tendrá espacios para niños, adolescentes y otros miembros de la comunidad, con el concepto final moldeado por la opinión de la comunidad.</p><p>Cristina De La Rosa, directora ejecutiva de Erie Neighborhood House, dijo que los miembros de la comunidad han expresado continuamente la necesidad de seguridad. La organización no lucrativa organizó grupos focales y distribuyó encuestas para escuchar más de los miembros de la comunidad sobre cómo sería un espacio seguro para los residentes y qué tipo de programación les gustaría ver en el nuevo centro.</p><p>“Queríamos ser realmente intencionales”, agregó De La Rosa. “Realmente queríamos asegurarnos de que cuando las personas ingresaran al edificio, sintieran que podían verse a sí mismas allí, que estaba diseñado para ellas”.</p><p>El resultado es un centro con un gimnasio de tamaño completo, salones flexibles, un estudio de artes, oficinas de consejería y terapia privadas, salones para adolescentes y tecnología, cocina comunitaria, espacios verdes al aire libre, un parque infantil en la azotea y un jardín infantil.</p><p>Erie Neighborhood House ya ofrece una serie de programas juveniles, pero el nuevo centro permitirá a la organización ofrecer programación de todo el día después de la escuela, dijo De La Rosa. Y durante el verano, los niños en edad escolar pueden quedarse durante la semana y recibir desayuno, almuerzo y un refrigerio.</p><p>Erie Neighborhood House espera comenzar la construcción este otoño y abrir dentro de un año después de su inauguración. El proyecto de $22 millones expandirá las oportunidades para que la organización no lucrativa se asocie con otras organizaciones en la zona como One Lawndale.</p><p>“No vemos esto como dos vecindarios separados”, dijo Townsell sobre North Lawndale y La Villita. “Vemos esto como un Lawndale y personas uniéndose para apoyar a los jóvenes”.</p><p>Rodríguez destacó que la fundación no tenía la intención de elegir a dos ganadores, y mucho menos dos de vecindarios adyacentes. Pero el premio está ayudando a conectar ambos proyectos con posibles socios de capital, duplicando su impacto previsto.</p><div class="Enhancement" data-align-center> <div class="Enhancement-item" data-crop=""> <figure class="Figure"><a class="AnchorLink" id="image-ff0000" name="image-ff0000"></a> <picture data-crop="medium"> <source type="image/webp" width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/b285353/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1235x693+0+4/resize/490x275!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0a%2Fc6%2F9880670a427aa01581599b9b39cd%2Fone-lawndale-recreation-center.jpeg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/6b9c6dd/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1235x693+0+4/resize/980x550!/format/webp/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0a%2Fc6%2F9880670a427aa01581599b9b39cd%2Fone-lawndale-recreation-center.jpeg 2x" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <source width="490" height="275" data-srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bf91fe7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1235x693+0+4/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0a%2Fc6%2F9880670a427aa01581599b9b39cd%2Fone-lawndale-recreation-center.jpeg" data-lazy-load="true" srcset="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" /> <img class="Image" alt="Boceto del centro comunitario One Lawndale de la Christian Development Corp. de North Lawndale, un proyecto que reemplazaría un antiguo lote de almacenamiento de la CTA. " srcset="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bf91fe7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1235x693+0+4/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0a%2Fc6%2F9880670a427aa01581599b9b39cd%2Fone-lawndale-recreation-center.jpeg 1x,https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/5c08ca3/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1235x693+0+4/resize/980x550!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0a%2Fc6%2F9880670a427aa01581599b9b39cd%2Fone-lawndale-recreation-center.jpeg 2x" width="490" height="275" data-src="https://cst.brightspotcdn.com/dims4/default/bf91fe7/2147483647/strip/true/crop/1235x693+0+4/resize/490x275!/quality/90/?url=https%3A%2F%2Fchorus-production-cst-web.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com%2Fbrightspot%2F0a%2Fc6%2F9880670a427aa01581599b9b39cd%2Fone-lawndale-recreation-center.jpeg" data-lazy-load="true" src="data:image/svg+xml;base64,PHN2ZyB4bWxucz0iaHR0cDovL3d3dy53My5vcmcvMjAwMC9zdmciIHZlcnNpb249IjEuMSIgaGVpZ2h0PSIyNzVweCIgd2lkdGg9IjQ5MHB4Ij48L3N2Zz4=" > </picture> <div class="Figure-content"><figcaption class="Figure-caption"><p>Boceto del centro comunitario One Lawndale de la Christian Development Corp. de North Lawndale, un proyecto que reemplazaría un antiguo lote de almacenamiento de la CTA.<br></p></figcaption><span class="line"></span><div class="Figure-credit"><p>Proporcionada por la Fundación Lohengrin</p></div></div> </figure> </div> </div><p>North Lawndale y La Villita tienen mayores números de jóvenes y violencia juvenil, según la fundación. El número de jóvenes que los proyectos servirían, junto con la viabilidad de cada proyecto, ayudó a elevar las dos propuestas.</p><p>Hubo más de 70 presentaciones para “Thriving Youth, Stronger Communities”, lo que muestra el entusiasmo por apoyar a las comunidades jóvenes, dijo Rodríguez.</p><p>“No hay límite en las ideas o en la necesidad. Sólo hay un límite en los recursos disponibles”, agregó.</p><p><i>Traducido con una herramienta de inteligencia artificial (AI) y editado por </i><a class="Link" href="https://chicago.suntimes.com/la-voz" target="_blank" ><i>La Voz Chicago</i></a></p>
